soc.message

Class SOCPlayerElements

  • java.lang.Object
    • soc.message.SOCMessage
      • soc.message.SOCMessageForGame
        • soc.message.SOCMessageTemplateMi
          • soc.message.SOCPlayerElements
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, SOCMessageMulti

    public class SOCPlayerElements
extends SOCMessageTemplateMi
    This message from the server sends information on some parts of a player's status, such as resource type counts. Same structure as SOCPlayerElement but with less overhead to send multiple similar element changes.

    For a given player number and action type, contains multiple pairs of (element type, amount).

    Defined in v1.1.09 but unused before v2.0.00, so getMinimumVersion() returns 2000.

    Since:
    1.1.09
    Author:
    Jeremy D Monin <jeremy@nand.net>
    See Also:
    SOCGameElements, Serialized Form

      • MIN_VERSION

        public static final int MIN_VERSION

        Same version as SOCPlayerElement.VERSION_FOR_CARD_ELEMENTS.

    • Constructor Detail

      • SOCPlayerElements

        public SOCPlayerElements(java.lang.String ga,
                         int pn,
                         int ac,
                         SOCPlayerElement.PEType[] et,
                         int[] amt)
                  throws java.lang.NullPointerException
        Constructor for server to tell client about player elements.
        Parameters:
        ga - name of the game
        pn - the player number
        ac - the type of action: SOCPlayerElement.SET, SOCPlayerElement.GAIN, or SOCPlayerElement.LOSE
        et - array of the types of element, such as SOCPlayerElement.PEType.SETTLEMENTS or SOCPlayerElement.PEType.WHEAT. For playing pieces in general, see SOCPlayerElement.elementTypeForPieceType(int).
        amt - array of the amounts to set or change each element, corresponding to et[]
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if et null or amt null, or et contains null values
        Since:
        2.3.00

      • SOCPlayerElements

        public SOCPlayerElements(java.lang.String ga,
                         int pn,
                         int ac,
                         SOCResourceSet rs)
                  throws java.lang.NullPointerException
        Constructor for server to tell client(s) about known player resources: SOCResourceConstants.CLAY through SOCResourceConstants.WOOD. Resource types with rs.getAmount(type) == 0 aren't sent.
        Parameters:
        ga - name of the game
        pn - the player number
        ac - the type of action: SOCPlayerElement.SET, SOCPlayerElement.GAIN, or SOCPlayerElement.LOSE
        rs - resource set, to send known resource types; SOCResourceConstants.UNKNOWN are ignored
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if rs null
        Since:
        2.0.00

    • Method Detail

      • getMinimumVersion

        public int getMinimumVersion()
        Minimum version where this message type is used (MIN_VERSION). PLAYERELEMENTS was introduced in v1.1.09 for the game-options feature but unused until 2.0.00.
        Overrides:
        getMinimumVersion in class SOCMessage
        Returns:
        Version number, 2000 for JSettlers 2.0.00.

      • getPlayerNumber

        public int getPlayerNumber()
        Returns:
        the player number; some elements allow -1 to apply to all players

      • getAction

        public int getAction()
        Returns:
        the action type: SOCPlayerElement.SET, SOCPlayerElement.GAIN, or SOCPlayerElement.LOSE

      • getElementTypes

        public int[] getElementTypes()
        Get the player info element types. These are ints to preserve values from unknown types from different versions. Converted to int at sending side with SOCPlayerElement.PEType.getValue(). To convert at receiving side to SOCPlayerElement.PETypes, use SOCPlayerElement.PEType.valueOf(int).
        Returns:
        the element types from SOCPlayerElement such as SOCPlayerElement.PEType.CLAY as ints, each matching up with the same-index item of parallel array getAmounts().

      • getAmounts

        public int[] getAmounts()
        Returns:
        the element amounts to set or change, matching up with each same-index item of getElementTypes().

        Before v2.0.00 this method was getValues().

      • parseDataStr

        public static SOCPlayerElements parseDataStr(java.util.List<java.lang.String> pa)
        Parse the command String list into a SOCPlayerElements message.
        Parameters:
        pa - the parameters; length 5 or more required. Built by constructor at server. Length must be odd. 
         pa[0] = gameName
 pa[1] = playerNum
 pa[2] = actionType
 pa[3] = elementType[0]
 pa[4] = amount[0]
 pa[5] = elementType[1]
 pa[6] = amount[1]
 ...
        Returns:
        a SOCPlayerElements message, or null if parsing errors

      • stripAttribsToList

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> stripAttribsToList(java.lang.String messageStrParams)
        Strip out the parameter/attribute names from toString()'s format, returning message parameters as a list for parseDataStr(List). Handles elemNum=value pairs, undoes mapping of action constant integers -> strings ("GAIN" etc).
        Parameters:
        messageStrParams - Params part of a message string formatted by toString(); not null
        Returns:
        Message parameters to finish parsing into a SOCMessage, or null if malformed
        Since:
        2.4.50

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Description copied from class: SOCMessage
        Simple human-readable delimited representation, used for debug purposes: SOCPutPiece:game=test5|playerNumber=3|pieceType=0|coord=40a
        Could also be used by a SOCServer.recordGameEvent(String, SOCMessage) implementation.

        Within this representation, message parameters should be in same order used by SOCMessage.toCmd() and parseDataStr(..). Should be parseable by SOCMessage.parseMsgStr(String) which calls SOCMessage.stripAttribNames(String), which your class can override if needed.

        Overrides:
        toString in class SOCMessageTemplateMi
        Returns:
        a human readable form of the message
        Since:
        2.0.00
        See Also:
        SOCMessage.toCmd()
